channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter From India: In Hindi Films, Strong Women Are a Formula That Works
item.description: The most popular Hindi films in recent months have been led by women. They have been made for the purest reason in commercial cinema: They make money.

item.title: European Central Bank Holds Rates Steady
item.description: The central bank left its benchmark rate at 0.05 percent, but said it intends to continue with its bond-purchasing program to stimulate the eurozone economy.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: China Keeps Lid on Information, as Hopes Dim in Yangtze Ship Disaster
item.description: Images and reporting from the site of the overturned vessel, the Oriental Star, were largely limited to state news outlets for the first 24 hours.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Rescue crews carried bodies recovered from the sunken ship on the Yangtze River on Wednesday.

item.title: Even in Safety of Malaysia, Rohingya Migrants Face Bleak Prospects
item.description: The arrivals who landed last month joined 75,000 others already there, but their marginalization in the region has muted their voice in the debate over their future.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rohingya Muslims prayed in a mosque near Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Interpol Issues Alerts for 6 After Sepp Blatter Says He’ll Quit
item.description: The so-called red notices, issued at the request of the United States, were for two former senior FIFA officials and four corporate executives.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Interpol's so-called red notice alert for two former senior FIFA officials and four corporate executives.

item.title: South Korea Says It Tested Missile That Can Strike Anywhere in North
item.description: The country has been developing a new ballistic missile since the U.S. agreed in 2012 to allow it to extend the range of those arms up to 500 miles.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Fear of MERS Virus Leads Over 230 South Korean Schools to Close
item.description: All of the country’s 30 reported cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome were tied to five hospitals, but the growing alarm reflected distrust of the government.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Tourists wearing protective masks in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday. Alarm was growing in the country over an outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Greece’s Runaway Train
item.description: No one is focusing on the day after a deal or a default, and on which outcome will offer the least pain.
item.dc:creator: NIKOS KONSTANDARAS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Deng Xiaoping Helped Create a Corrupt China
item.description: He famously said the Communist Party would have to let some people get rich first. He didn’t say who.
item.dc:creator: BAO TONG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rival Pro-Democracy Rallies Planned for June 4 in Hong Kong
item.description: The various demonstrations are a reflection of growing divisions over Hong Kong’s identity, its relationship with the Chinese mainland and where democracy advocates should concentrate their efforts.
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
item.dc:creator: CRYSTAL TSE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: The candlelight vigil in Victoria Park in 2012 marking the 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen protests. A poll has found waning support for the vigil’s organizer.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Willy Wo-Lap Lam on ‘Chinese Politics in the Era of Xi Jinping’
item.description: Willy Wo-Lap Lam, a 62-year-old professor at Chinese University of Hong Kong. is the author of five books analyzing China’s top leaders since Zhao Ziyang.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, who has veered away from the “first among equals” approach in favor of the “big boss” model, according to the China scholar Willy Wo-Lap Lam.

item.title: Airstrikes in Yemen Kill Allies of Saudi-Led Coalition, Witnesses Say
item.description: The coalition killed at least 16 of its own allies, including three senior leaders, according to a fighter who was near the site of the bombing.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: Sepp Blatter Decides to Resign as FIFA President in About-Face
item.description: Four days after he was re-elected, Mr. Blatter said that he would resign his presidency of world soccer’s governing body in the wake of a corruption inquiry.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: Sepp Blatter said FIFA was in need of "a profound overhaul."

item.title: Families Tell Lawmakers of Americans Held Hostage in Iran
item.description: The relatives of four United States citizens were pressing the Obama administration to do more to free the captives before the June 30 deadline for reaching an international agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Assad’s Forces May Be Aiding New ISIS Surge
item.description: Insurgents opposed to the Islamic State said the group was exploiting Syrian government airstrikes against them to seize areas near Aleppo.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Support for the European Union Is Rising, Survey Suggests
item.description: A poll carried out in France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Spain and Britain found that a more resilient European economy was helping to restore faith in the bloc.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: U.N. Dismayed by Decline
item.description: The United Nations expressed alarm over the recent heavy fighting that had displaced more than 100,000 people and blocked aid deliveries to 650,000.
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Economic Scene: Climate Deal Badly Needs a Big Stick
item.description: Fruitless efforts to seriously curb greenhouse gas pollution suggest a new approach is warranted — making it costly not to join an international consortium committed to fighting climate change.
item.dc:creator: EDUARDO PORTER
item.media:description: A coal train in Printer, Ky. A proposed international tariff system would make it costly for the United States not to sign onto a reduced-emissions regime.

item.title: U.S. Envoy Held Talks With Houthi Rebels of Yemen
item.description: Anne W. Patterson, the American envoy, met last week in Oman with the Houthis to discuss violence in Yemen and the capture of several Americans.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Decline of North Sea Oil Fields Forces Political Shifts in Britain
item.description: The dropping revenue has inspired changes of tactics by British leaders as well as Scottish nationalists, who had counted on oil as an economic mainstay.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED
